TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit SqlBulkCopyColumnMapping extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Defines the mapping between a column in a instance's data source and a column in the instance's destination table.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Column mappings define the mapping between data source and the target table.
If mappings are not defined—that is, the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlBulkCopy.ColumnMappings%2A> collection is empty—the columns are mapped implicitly based on ordinal position. For this to work, source and target schemas must match. If they do not, an <xref:System.InvalidOperationException> will be thrown.
If the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlBulkCopy.ColumnMappings%2A> collection is not empty, not every column present in the data source has to be specified. Those not mapped by the collection are ignored.
You can refer to source and target columns by either name or ordinal. You can also mix by-name and by-ordinal column references in the same mappings collection.
## Examples The following example bulk copies data from a source table in the **AdventureWorks** sample database to a destination table in the same database. Although the number of columns in the destination matches the number of columns in the source, and each destination column is in the same ordinal position as its corresponding source column, the column names do not match. SqlBulkCopyColumnMapping objects are used to create a column map for the bulk copy.
> [!IMPORTANT] > This sample will not run unless you have created the work tables as described in [Bulk Copy Example Setup](../Topic/Bulk%20Copy%20Example%20Setup.md). This code is provided to demonstrate the syntax for using **SqlBulkCopy** only. If the source and destination tables are in the same SQL Server instance, it is easier and faster to use a Transact-SQL `INSERT … SELECT` statement to copy the data.
[!code-vb[DataWorks SqlBulkCopy.ColumnMapping#1](../../add/codesnippet/VisualBasic/t-system.data.sqlclient._11_1.vb)] [!code-cs[DataWorks SqlBulkCopy.ColumnMapping#1](../../add/codesnippet/CSharp/t-system.data.sqlclient._11_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Default constructor that initializes a new object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If you use this constructor, you must then define the source for the mapping using the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlBulkCopyColumnMapping.SourceColumn%2A> property or the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlBulkCopyColumnMapping.SourceOrdinal%2A> property, and define the destination for the mapping using the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlBulkCopyColumnMapping.DestinationColumn%2A> property or the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlBulkCopyColumnMapping.DestinationOrdinal%2A> property.
## Examples The following example bulk copies data from a source table in the **AdventureWorks** sample database to a destination table in the same database. Although the number of columns in the destination matches the number of columns in the source, the column names and ordinal positions do not match. <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlBulkCopyColumnMapping> objects are used to create a column map for the bulk copy.
> [!IMPORTANT] > This sample will not run unless you have created the work tables as described in [Bulk Copy Example Setup](../Topic/Bulk%20Copy%20Example%20Setup.md). This code is provided to demonstrate the syntax for using **SqlBulkCopy** only. If the source and destination tables are in the same SQL Server instance, it is easier and faster to use a Transact-SQL `INSERT … SELECT` statement to copy the data.
[!code-vb[DataWorks SqlBulkCopy.ColumnMapping#1](../../add/codesnippet/VisualBasic/m-system.data.sqlclient._33_1.vb)] [!code-cs[DataWorks SqlBulkCopy.ColumnMapping#1](../../add/codesnippet/CSharp/m-system.data.sqlclient._33_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(int32 sourceColumnOrdinal, int32 destinationOrdinal) cil managed

Docs.param: The ordinal position of the source column within the data source.
The ordinal position of the destination column within the destination table.
Docs.summary: Creates a new column mapping, using column ordinals to refer to source and destination columns.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example bulk copies data from a source table in the **AdventureWorks** sample database to a destination table in the same database. Although the number of columns in the destination matches the number of columns in the source, the column names and ordinal positions do not match. <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlBulkCopyColumnMapping> objects are used to create a column map for the bulk copy based on the ordinal positions of the columns.
> [!IMPORTANT] > This sample will not run unless you have created the work tables as described in [Bulk Copy Example Setup](../Topic/Bulk%20Copy%20Example%20Setup.md). This code is provided to demonstrate the syntax for using **SqlBulkCopy** only. If the source and destination tables are in the same SQL Server instance, it is easier and faster to use a Transact-SQL `INSERT … SELECT` statement to copy the data.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(int32 sourceColumnOrdinal, string destinationColumn) cil managed

Docs.param: The ordinal position of the source column within the data source.
The name of the destination column within the destination table.
Docs.summary: Creates a new column mapping, using a column ordinal to refer to the source column and a column name for the target column.

Docs.summary: Name of the column being mapped in the destination database table.
Docs.value: The string value of the DestinationColumn property.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The DestinationColumn and <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlBulkCopyColumnMapping.DestinationOrdinal%2A> properties are mutually exclusive. The last value set takes precedence.
## Examples The following example bulk copies data from a source table in the **AdventureWorks** sample database to a destination table in the same database. Although the number of columns in the destination matches the number of columns in the source, the column names and ordinal positions do not match. <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlBulkCopyColumnMapping> objects are used to create a column map for the bulk copy.

Docs.returns: The string value of the DestinationColumn property.

Docs.summary: Ordinal value of the destination column within the destination table.
Docs.value: The integer value of the DestinationOrdinal property, or -1 if the property has not been set.

remarks.format:
